unnormalised: New Delhi: India's commitment to renewable energy is gaining significant traction, driven by innovative policies and grassroots initiatives. Dr. Meena Sharma, a leading environmental scientist at IIT Bombay, highlights the crucial role of solar power in achieving India's ambitious climate goals.
normalised: New Delhi: India's commitment to renewable energy is gaining significant traction, driven by innovative policies and grassroots initiatives. Doctor Meena Sharma, a leading environmental scientist at I I T Bombay, highlights the crucial role of solar power in achieving India's ambitious climate goals.

unnormalised: The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) recently announced a new scheme to incentivize rooftop solar installations in residential areas. This program aims to add 10,000 MW of solar capacity by 2026, significantly reducing reliance on fossil fuels.
normalised: The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (M N R E) recently announced a new scheme to incentivize rooftop solar installations in residential areas. This program aims to add ten thousand megawatt of solar capacity by two thousand twenty six, significantly reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

unnormalised: Rajasthan, with its abundant sunshine, is emerging as a hub for solar energy. The Bhadla Solar Park, one of the world's largest, sprawls across 14,000 acres (approximately 605 million sq ft) and generates enough electricity to power millions of homes.
normalised: Rajasthan, with its abundant sunshine, is emerging as a hub for solar energy. The Bhadla Solar Park, one of the world's largest, sprawls across fourteen thousand acres (approximately six hundred and five million square feet) and generates enough electricity to power millions of homes.

unnormalised: Beyond large-scale projects, local communities are embracing renewable solutions. In several villages, solar-powered microgrids are providing electricity to homes and businesses, showcasing the potential for sustainable development. Challenges remain, including land acquisition and financing, but the momentum is undeniably building. Experts predict that Indiaâ€™s renewable energy sector will attract investments of Rs. 20 lakh crore in the next decade.
normalised: Beyond large-scale projects, local communities are embracing renewable solutions. In several villages, solar-powered microgrids are providing electricity to homes and businesses, showcasing the potential for sustainable development. Challenges remain, including land acquisition and financing, but the momentum is undeniably building. Experts predict that India's renewable energy sector will attract investments of rupees twenty lakh crore in the next decade.
